captions.text:
- Panda Express to me is like
white people's Chinese food.
- Wow, this looks like a candle.
- It's like soggy on the inside.

- If you actually know
real Chinese chow mein,

you'd be like, "This is
American Chinese chow mein."
- Ew, it smells like stinky feet.
- I think it's not that bad.

- Wow, you've never had
authentic Chinese food before.
- I'd rather eat this than the egg roll,
- That's how I end up with her.
- He looks down at Panda Express,
but he eats McDonald's all the time.

- If you blind folded me,
I'm eating plain rice.
- Yeah, I do not like that.
- This reminds me of taking shots,
Like if he were here, he would hate this.
- Really? I feel like it smells weird.
- Orange chicken is not real Chinese food.

My mom calls it the food
that fools Americans.
- Oh, no, no, no, I know what this is.
- Not sure what that is, you know.
- He had to finish all his orange chicken.

- I can't imagine anyone
thinking that Panda's

- But you know what my
dad used to always say

is that you can't leave one
grain of rice on the plate.

- [Melanie] Yeah, that's
what my mom always said too,
so I don't like wasting food.

- Right, did you not get that
when you were younger too?

title: Chinese People Try Panda Express For The First Time

comments.text:
Idk... after trying americanized chinese food for a long time, i liked the 
americanized chinese food than the authentic chinese food itself﻿
comments.author: B Ray

comments.text:
My grandma's brother-in-law, who is my uncle from Hong Kong, ate the 
Americanized Chinese food and said that it sucks. In addition, he said it 
insults actual Chinese food.﻿
comments.author: That Chinese Guy翰林

comments.text:
"Low standards"
"That's how I end up with her" 

Am I the only one who heard that?﻿

What is with the whitest Chinese kids saying shit about every thing and the

comments.text: East China inn is way better than panda express.﻿

comments.text: the Chinese people speak mandarin and Cantonese﻿
comments.author: bob lame

comments.text:
This is silly, food in China is so regional that they'll be split in 
opinion on whether it's authentic or not depending on the provinces in 
which they're from and what styles of cooking they're used to.﻿
comments.author: Derin Halil

comments.text:
But the guy in the gray shirt tht was bashing the food the whole time was 
inhaling the rice at the end 😑...😏guess it wasn't so bad after all﻿

Find some Chinese tourists and ask them what it taste like, that'll bring

comments.text: no ill pass i perfer piranha killer sushi over that 100% anytime﻿
comments.author: Roland Mendoza

comments.text:
I love how all the younger people jumped on the hate-wagon. They heard 
Panda Express and were like "oh this is gross" I bet if they didn't know it 
was Panda Express they would like it.﻿
comments.author: SovietIVIan

comments.text:
Awww... I was thinking that the older generation would definitely not like 
this. But pleasantly surprised that they were open minded. The kids on the 
other hand... hmm... well, I guess they're entitled. I live and work in 
Hong Kong -- HK people aren't snobbish about whether food is "authentic" or 
not - it all comes down to personal taste right? Besides, everything here 
is basically "fusion" - east meets west.﻿
comments.author: Agatha Xaris Villa

comments.text: American identity problems in a nutshell.﻿

comments.text:

comments.text:
Funny how the young people who have probably never even had real Chinese 
food are against it. But the older people who probably grew up eating real 
Chinese food have no problem with it...﻿
comments.author: Julia Smith

comments.text:
The very first guy to speak sounds so pretentious throughout the whole 
video. I love how the girl on his left calls him out on it too.

The old people were very sweet. Even if they disliked it, they didn't act 
like it was the worst thing they'd ever tasted. I also like the red haired 
woman's quote at the end. If you replace the word Chinese with just about 
any other nationality/region/culture, it definitely remains true of just 
about any restaurant.﻿
comments.author: Austin Gremminger

comments.text:
It's obvious the elderly say exactly what they think and the younger crowd 
just put on a show. Elderly reviews are the ones to go by﻿

comments.text:
I see much of the same thing in America when it comes to My food heritage 
"Cajun Food" So many people outside of Southern Louisiana will add hot 
sauce or red pepper and call it Cajun. Older Cajuns like the Older Chinese 
people in this video are polite about it but You know they really do not 
care for the food.﻿

comments.text:
In most asian culture it is impolite to say bad things about food that is 
served to us. And as you can see the chinese old people just compliment or 
say the food is not tht bad. This is a proof tht these folks still retain 
this asian value, while the younger generation and in this case the 
westernised Chinese has lost it.﻿

comments.author: Khang Kent Xuan NGuyen

comments.text:
Well Panda Express is basically fast food I don't think anyone would 
consider it authentic. A lot of the elder folks in the video seemed to 
enjoy a lot of the dishes as being pretty tasty so it's doing it's job 
okay. I honestly don't know where I would truly get authentic chinese food 
from in Texas where I am from. I order chines take out from time to time 
but their cooks are latino guys lol. The younger people in this video 
seemed pretty obnoxious honestly the older folks were so adorable.﻿
comments.author: supersqueak

comments.text:
LOL the elders sure did approve of panda's chinese food. For the most part 
they liked every plate except the sweet and sour soup. The younger kids, 
the two girls and one douche bag, didn't seem so fond of the food. As if 
admitting the food was okay was like throwing the chinese flag in the fire. 
He was sure shoveling his face in the end with the same rice he said was 
plain... good job asshole. you fail at being real.﻿

comments.text:
Not addressing Panda Express, but here is food for thought (no pun 
intended), outside the big cities, especially away from New York and San 
Francisco, if you go into a Chinese restaurant and ask the people where 
they are from, you will often find they are not Chinese! Most commonly, I 
have found them to be Vietnamese, but also other nationalities, as well.﻿

Im Mexican and what Americans believe is Mexican food, I believe is garbage 
no real taste, I can cook Mexican food but not with American Ingredients or 
American meat it all has to be in mexico or close to the border to have 
almost the same taste.

Just because that kids parents make chinese food in his house, it does not 
mean it is real chinese food as it is being made with American ingredients.
Plus Chinese food in china is mostly made with dog and cat meat.﻿
